awd_abstract_narration:
New technologies and techniques in robotics (miniature fabrication), computational biology (DNA assembly), material science (nano-technology), and even origami give rise to new questions in kinematic design ? the design of moving assemblies.  This project addresses the theory and corresponding algorithms for a number of fundamental problems in kinematic design. The goal is to design the shape of a (deformable) geometric object, along with one or a family of its deformation trajectories. In robotics, for instance, one may want to build a robot arm capable of moving its end-effector from any point in a source domain to any point in a destination domain (geometric structure design), in a way that would avoid singularities and collisions (trajectory design). In manufacturing and CAD, one is interested in designing structures that can be assembled from standard smaller parts; for example, a polyhedral surface might be assembled from rigid triangular pieces whose sides are joined together. Another example is folding a 3D origami shape from a creased piece of (flat) paper: both the 3D shape and the folding trajectories have to be designed in advance. The results are anticipated to have an impact on several scientific fields where geometric modeling and geometric simulations are being used, including mechanics, robotics, computational biology and materials science (nano-technology).  The project will engage a diverse population of students, at all levels (post-doc, graduate and undergraduate). The PIs will develop new educational materials related to emerging multidisciplinary connections.

New kinematic design principles rely on the mutual dependence of mobility and structure. Recent results of the PIs on robot-arm singularities and precise positional workspace determination provide insights and techniques for an integrated approach, which coordinates structural parameters and path-planning. For innovative patterns of metamaterials with auxetic capabilities, a rigorous geometric theory of periodic frameworks will be combined with efficient algorithms  for framework generation and visualization. Advancing these methods will throw new light on conformational changes in crystals and biological self-assembly problems.

por.por_cntn:
The project's main theoretical findings, technical developments, algorithms and design methodology, concern the theory of periodic frameworks and geometric auxetics. For both, we have relied on foundations laid out in our previous work. As mathematical theories, both operate in arbitrary dimension, but for applications, the relevant dimensions are two and three.

Periodic frameworks represent an extension of the classical theory of finite linkages, or articulated mechanical systems, to an infinite setting, where a finite quality is maintained through symmetry (periodicity, repetitiveness). Crystalline structures, imagined as infinite, are typical examples.

The deformation theory of periodic frameworks is a study of kinematics in this infinite setting, where motions are supposed to preserve periodicity and the length of all links. Geometric auxetics refers to a particularly relevant deformation behavior or "growth", whereby stretching in a given direction is accompanied by lateral widening. Thus, the project's results have bearing on several applications with interdisciplinary character, involving crystallography, computational biology, engineering, materials science and metamaterial design.

The general theory of periodic frameworks was developed and refined in the following directions:

(i) studies of global deformation spaces, where mathematical techniques offer clear advantages over experimental approaches, usually limited to small deformations;

(ii) identification of intrinsic kinematic characteristics, where a key result proves the existence of a signature invariant and recognizes auxetic deformations as those with highest possible signature;

(iii) techniques for controlled reduction of degrees of freedom in a given framework, since targeted functionality requires elimination of irrelevant deformations;

(iv) algoritms for detecting auxetic capabilities in certain classes of frameworks, for instace those consisting of vertex-connected tetrahedra.

 Our general methodology for auxetic design shows not only unlimited possibilities, but organizes this infinity by structural criteria which take into account the graph valency, the number of periodicity orbits, the dimension of the deformation space or the volume variation over an auxetic interval. Moreover, our recent results on saturation and cognate periodic frameworks, which are frameworks with the same kinematics, but with distinct periodic graphs, show that abstract structural criteria are imperative for auxetic design classification. For planar periodic frameworks, a remarkable class of auxetic designs with one degree of freedom is provided by periodic pseudo-triangulations.
